data.question: What is the yield of isolated crystalline product when preparing sodium tris(amido)ferrate [(dioxane)0.5·NaFe(HMDS)3] (1)?
What reaction conditions are required for the ferration of fluoroarenes using sodium ferrate 1?
data.answer: Reactions were carried out in benzene, allowing mixtures to stir overnight prior to I2 quenching.

data.question: Is sodium-mediated ferration possible without the presence of sodium in the reaction?
data.answer: No, sodium is essential for the reaction to occur.

data.question: What happens to the C@H and C@F bonds in the presence of excess sodium ferrate 1 at 80-88°C?
data.answer: Each C@H bond is transformed to a C@Fe bond whereas each C@F bond is transformed into a C@N bond.

data.question: What is the yield of heteroleptic [(dioxane)·NaFe(HMDS)2(1,3-F2-C6H3)] (2) when reacting 1,3-difluorobenzene with equimolar 1 at room temperature?
Can sodium ferrate 1 react with related chloroarenes under the studied conditions?
data.answer: No, 1 failed to react with related chloroarenes.

data.question: What is the outcome of treating diferrated product 4a with one equivalent of sodium ferrate 1 or just one equivalent of Na(HMDS) at 80 88C?
data.answer: Formation of unimetallic iron complex [1,3-{Fe(HMDS)}2-2,4,6-(HMDS)2-C6H] (5a) in excellent yield (90-95%).

data.question: Does the ferration of fluoroarenes using sodium ferrate 1 require high temperatures?
data.answer: False, the ferration occurs under mild reaction conditions.

data.question: What is the structural feature of the iron bis(amide) Fe(HMDS)2?
data.answer: Fe(HMDS)2 has low polarity of its Fe@N bonds.

data.question: Is the ferrated intermediate 2 stable under reflux conditions?
data.answer: True, ferrated intermediate 2 does not decompose even when refluxed in C6D6 at 80-88°C for 24 hours.

data.question: What is the effect of using excess sodium ferrate 1 on the reaction with 1,3,5-trifluorobenzene?
data.answer: It induces a cascade process resulting in the collective twofold C@H/threefold C@F bond activations.

data.question: What is the yield of 1,3-difluoro-2-iodobenzene 3a when intercepting heteroleptic [(dioxane)·NaFe(HMDS)2(1,3-F2-C6H3)] (2) with iodine?
Is the reaction of sodium ferrate 1 with fluoroarenes selective towards C@H bond activation over C@F bond activation?
data.answer: True, selective Fe–H exchange reactions are observed over C@F bond activation.

data.question: What is the role of sodium in the sodium-mediated ferration process?
data.answer: Sodium is essential for the reaction to occur, facilitating the deprotonation process.

data.question: Can sodium ferrate 1 directly activate C@F bonds in fluoroarenes?
data.answer: False, the study primarily focuses on C@H bond activation, though a novel C@F bond activation process for C@N bond conversion is disclosed.

data.question: What is the significance of the sodium ferrate base [(dioxane)0.5·NaFe(HMDS)3] (1) in the study?
data.answer: It enables regioselective mono and di-ferration of fluoroaromatic substrates under mild conditions.

data.question: Does the presence of other ortho-directing groups in fluoroarenes affect the regioselectivity of metallation?
data.answer: No, ortho-metallation at the F substituent is preferred even in the presence of other ortho-directing groups.

data.question: What is the outcome of heating diferrated intermediate 4a on its own in benzene at 80 88C?
data.answer: Formation of unimetallic iron complex [1,3-{Fe(HMDS)}2-2,4,6-(HMDS)2-C6H] (5a), albeit in a significantly lower yield (58%).

data.question: Is the reaction of sodium ferrate 1 with fluoroarenes a novel approach in organoiron chemistry?
data.answer: True, the study discloses a new method for regioselective functionalisation of fluoroarenes via direct ferration.

data.question: What is the role of Na···F interactions in the sodium-mediated ferration process?
data.answer: Na···F interactions may facilitate the activation of relevant C@F bonds under certain reaction conditions.
